qas.question: The clashes between Ehl-i Sunna and Shia had what kind of character?
Islamic political philosophy was rooted in what sources?
What is taken as the basis of an analysis?
What political philosophy was rooted in theology?

plausible_answers.text: kudrah (power), sultan, ummah, cemaa (obligation)-and even the "core" terms of the Qur'an—i.e., ibadah (worship), din (religion), rab (master) and ilah (deity)

qas.question: What are the religious conceptions of Islam?
What clashed up until the seventh and eighth century?
What is the religious conception of Islam taken as?
What kind of character did the clashes between Bajjah and Rushd have in the 7th and 8th centuries?

plausible_answers.text: Qur'an and the Sunnah, the words and practices of Muhammad

qas.question: What sources are Avicenna based on?

plausible_answers.text: it was a specific area peculiar merely to the great philosophers of Islam

qas.question: How did the ilah generally suppose Islamic philosophy was rooted?
What did Ehl-i-Sunna and Shia pose regarding Islam?
What do the ideas of general political character give proof of in early Islamic history?

context: <b3_0>Islamic<b3_0/> political philosophy, was, indeed, rooted in the very sources of <a1_0>Islam<a1_0/>—i.e., the <b8_0>Qur'an and the Sunnah, the words and practices of Muhammad<b8_0/>—thus making it essentially theocratic. However, in the Western thought, it is generally supposed that <b9_0>it was a specific area peculiar merely to the great philosophers of Islam<b9_0/>: al-Kindi (Alkindus), al-Farabi (Abunaser), İbn Sina (Avicenna), Ibn Bajjah (Avempace), Ibn Rushd (Averroes), and Ibn Khaldun. <a2_0>The political conceptions of Islam<a2_0/> such as <b4_0>kudrah (power), sultan, ummah, cemaa (obligation)-and even the "core" terms of the Qur'an—i.e., ibadah (worship), din (religion), rab (master) and ilah (deity)<b4_0/>—is taken as the <b6_0>basis of an analysis<b6_0/>. Hence, not only the ideas of the Muslim political philosophers but also many other jurists and ulama posed <b10_0>political ideas and theories<b10_0/>. For example, the ideas of the Khawarij in the very early years of Islamic history on Khilafa and Ummah, or that of Shia Islam on the concept of Imamah are considered proofs of <b11_0>political thought<b11_0/>. The clashes between the <b5_0>Ehl-i Sunna and Shia<b5_0/> in the 7th and 8th centuries had a <b7_0>genuine <a0_0>political<a0_0/> character<b7_0/>.
